newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast crudes stay firm, buyers sidelined.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast crudes stay firm, buyers sidelined.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crude prices continued rising with a strong spot market late Tuesday, following news the U.S. launched missile attacks against Iraq in response to the country's attack on a U.N. protected zone.
WTI cash for October delivery rose around $1.10 a barrel to $23.30/40 in the wake of the NYMEX-fuelled rally, which saw October values jump $1.15 to $24.25.
But the rise frightened off Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude buyers, who waited for prices to drop before re-entering the market. The last deal was done at $2.05 under October WTI.
A major seller offered ANS at $2 off October WTI, while a buyer bid at $2.45 under.
Outright prices rose to $21.15/21.45 a barrel, up $1.10 from Friday levels.
Values for Kern River reacted to Tuesday's higher posted prices, edging up 10 cents to end $14.10/14.60 a barrel.
Line 63 differentials were unchanged at WTI minus $2.60/2.50 a barrel, with little trading seen ahead of mid-September.
BP, a major ANS producer, bought part of an unusually large spot volume of Alberta crude last week, traders said.

One buyer speculated BP may have purchased the grade, a competitor to ANS, to ease the undermining effect of excess Canadian crudes. The grades have come West in September because of maintenance on a large Canadian pipeline.
But another trader said it was only a "fair buy" for BP.
Texaco last week purchased a large piece of the Canadian offering, at a slight premium to ANS.
One trader said the price for the grade -- a lighter, more lucrative crude to process -- was the cheapest it had been for months.
